natural problem: Each of five, standard, six-sided dice is rolled once. Two of the dice come up the same, but the other three are all different from those two and different from each other. The pair is set aside, and the other three dice are re-rolled. The dice are said to show a "full house" if three of the dice show the same value and the other two show the same value (and potentially, but not necessarily, all five dice show the same value). What is the probability that after the second set of rolls, the dice show a full house?
natural solution: There are a total of $6^3=216$ possible sets of dice rolls. If one of the re-rolled dice matches the pair we set aside and the other two form a pair, we will have a full house. But we will also have a full house if all three re-rolled dice come up the same.

Consider the first case. There are $3$ ways to pick which of the three dice will match a pair, and then $5$ ways to pick a value for the other two dice so that they form a pair (but don't match the first three dice), for a total of $3\cdot 5=15$ possible outcomes, plus the outcome that all five dice match.

In the second case, we need all three dice to match each other. There are $5$ ways to pick which value the three dice will have so that they don't match the first pair, plus the outcome that all five dice match.
So there are a total of $15+5=20$ ways to get a full house without all five dice matching, added to the possibility that all five dice match, which makes $21$ ways to get a full house.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> P"
and h1 : "P \<le> 1"
and h2 : "P = probability_of_full_house_after_second_roll"
shows  "P = 7 / 72"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of five, standard, six-sided dice is rolled once. Two of the dice come up the same, but the other three are all different from those two and different from each other. The pair is set aside, and the other three dice are re-rolled. The dice are said to show a "full house" if three of the dice show the same value and the other two show the same value (and potentially, but not necessarily, all five dice show the same value). What is the probability that after the second set of rolls, the dice show a full house? The final Answer is \frac{7}{72}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^3=216$ possible sets of dice rolls. If one of the re-rolled dice matches the pair we set aside and the other two form a pair, we will have a full house. But we will also have a full house if all three re-rolled dice come up the same.
 Consider the first case. There are $3$ ways to pick which of the three dice will match a pair, and then $5$ ways to pick a value for the other two dice so that they form a pair (but don't match the first three dice), for a total of $3\cdot 5=15$ possible outcomes, plus the outcome that all five dice match.
 In the second case, we need all three dice to match each other. There are $5$ ways to pick which value the three dice will have so that they don't match the first pair, plus the outcome that all five dice match.
 So there are a total of $15+5=20$ ways to get a full house without all five dice matching, added to the possibility that all five dice match, which makes $21$ ways to get a full house.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{21}{216}=\boxed{\frac{7}{72}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> P"
and h1 : "P \<le> 1"
and h2 : "P = probability_of_full_house_after_second_roll"
shows  "P = 7 / 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the probability of getting a full house after the second roll in a dice game, given that the probability is between 0 and 1. The final answer is $\frac{7}{72}$.

fixes P :: "rat"

theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> P"
and h1 : "P \<le> 1"

shows  "P = probability_space.full_house (5, 6)"
a_5.formal solution:

 Each of five, standard, six-sided dice is rolled once. Two of the dice come up the same, but the other three are all different from those two and different from each other. fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> P"
and h1 : "P \<le> 1"
and h2 : "P = (7 / 72)"
shows  "P = probability_space.full_house (5, 6)"

a_5.informal problem: What is the probability of getting a full house in a 5-card hand when playing with a 6-sided die? The final answer is $\frac{7}{72}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes full_house_probability :: real
assumes h0 : "full_house_probability = (\<Sum> x \<in> {1..6} . (\<Sum> y \<in> {1..6} - {x} . (\<Sum> z \<in> {1..6} - {x,y} . (1/6 * 1/6 * 1/6 * 1/6 * 1/6) * 
                          (if x = z then 3 else 0) + (if y = z then 2 else 0) + (if x = y then 1 else 0))))"
shows  "full_house_probability = 7 / 72"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of five, standard, six-sided dice is rolled once. Two of the dice come up the same, but the other three are all different from those two and different from each other. The pair is set aside, and the other three dice are re-rolled. The dice are said to show a "full house" if three of the dice show the same value and the other two show the same value (and potentially, but not necessarily, all five dice show the same value). What is the probability that after the second set of rolls, the dice show a full house? The final Answer is \frac{7}{72}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^3=216$ possible sets of dice rolls. If one of the re-rolled dice matches the pair we set aside and the other two form a pair, we will have a full house. But we will also have a full house if all three re-rolled dice come up the same.
 Consider the first case. There are $3$ ways to pick which of the three dice will match a pair, and then $5$ ways to pick a value for the other two dice so that they form a pair (but don't match the first three dice), for a total of $3\cdot 5=15$ possible outcomes, plus the outcome that all five dice match.
 In the second case, we need all three dice to match each other. There are $5$ ways to pick which value the three dice will have so that they don't match the first pair, plus the outcome that all five dice match.
 So there are a total of $15+5=20$ ways to get a full house without all five dice matching, added to the possibility that all five dice match, which makes $21$ ways to get a full house.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{21}{216}=\boxed{\frac{7}{72}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes full_house_probability :: real
assumes h0 : "full_house_probability = (\<Sum> x \<in> {1..6} . (\<Sum> y \<in> {1..6} - {x} . (\<Sum> z \<in> {1..6} - {x,y} . (1/6 * 1/6 * 1/6 * 1/6 * 1/6) * 
                          (if x = z then 3 else 0) + (if y = z then 2 else 0) + (if x = y then 1 else 0))))"
shows  "full_house_probability = 7 / 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Calculate the probability of getting a full house in a dice game, where a full house is defined as having three dice showing the same number and the other two dice showing another number. The final answer is $\frac{7}{72}$.
